nodes.bodyText: In addition to removing hasSemantic() check, you can also remove this test.
Nope. Even if we remove the hasSemantic() check, we still want to check how the rule implementation behaves with a lot of unknown symbols. So .withoutSemantic() is still useful. #UnknownSymbolsMatter
Same here, you can remove it.

I understand that you wanted to follow the same pattern as raiseIssueOnNotCompliantModifiers, but this code can report an issue only in one of the children, does it make sense to keep it in the common part?
